intro: Dendrophthora arcuata, commonly known as the waxy tree moss, is a member of the family Dendrophoraceae and is characterized by its unique morphology and ecological adaptations. It is a cryptogamic plant that typically grows on the bark of trees, forming dense, cushion-like colonies. The plant exhibits a complex structure with a central axis and lateral branches, covered in a thick layer of waxy cuticle that helps it retain moisture. Its reproductive structures are hidden beneath the vegetative layers, and it relies on spore dispersal for propagation. Dendrophthora arcuata is often found in humid, shaded environments, contributing to the biodiversity of forest ecosystems.
